layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in three lines, reading vertically downwards (Edwards 2013, 346). The inscription is incised with a punch.. Macalister argued for the presence of a fragmentary Ogham inscription on the bottom left edge of the face of the stone (Macalister 1945, 377). This inscription is not visible in the Welsh Corpus illustrations (Edwards 2013, 346-8).

handDesc.handNote: The Roman-letters are described as capitals with minuscule S in line 3. In line 1, the lower bow of the B is larger than the upper which does not meet the vertical, the loop of the R is open and the tiny diagonal curves towards the horizontal, O's are small, MA are ligatured, slightly curved and sprawling, G is uncial and looks like an S, the horizontal of L slants slightly upwards. In line 2, the first C is slightly angular, the right diagonal bar tilts upwards. In line 3, the V's are slightly rounded, T is small, O is small and slightly angular, R has an open loop and the short diagonal veers towards the horizontal, AV and NE are ligatured, but the bottom of the second stroke of the N is seperate from the small E above it (Edwards 2013, 346). The Welsh Corpus notes that the layout of the inscription and the size of individual letters is affected by the need to avoid damaged and laminated areas of the face...the first two lines of the inscription are in larger letters than the third (Edwards 2013, 348). The size difference could reflect a lack of space or that the third line was added later than the first two which in turn might reflect a lower status of the person commemorated in the third line (Edwards 2013, 348).

history.provenance: According to CISP, Macalister(1945, 377), is the only authority to have seen ogham on this stone. His drawing shows four ends of ogham under the third line of Latin along the break, but this doesn't seem to be there in the Welsh Corpus photograph.
Mounted horizontally on the wall of the summer house at Voelas (SH 8503 5152).

div.p: Latin: 'of Brohomaglus Iattus, here he lies, and his wifeCaune'

The Roman-letter inscription commemorates a husband and wife. Inscriptions commemorating wife and husband together is also seen on Llangefni 1 (AN39) and Llansadwrn 1 (AN45). On the structure of the inscription, the Welsh Corpus notes that Brohomagli is followed by the patronym Iatti, both in the genitive case...in line 3, vxor ('wife') is in the nominative, followed by eivs in the genitive and Cavne is also in the genitive, indicating the breakdown of the Latin case-system (Edwards 2013, 347-8). Speaking to the character and origin of the names in the inscription, the Welsh Corpus comments that BROHOMAGLI is an earlier from of W. Brochfael...'badger-prince'...than is seen in BROHCMAIL/BROHCMAL on Llandysilio yn Iâl 1 (D3). Quite likely Llandysul 1 (CD14), BROHO[, had the same form. IATTI...may be a hypocoristic variant of the Celtic name-element Iantu- 'jealousy, emulation', as in Old Breton names in Iat- and Gaulish Iatta. CAVNE probably corresponds to Latin names in Caun-, of uncertain etymology, such as Caunus and Caunia (Edwards 2013, 348).

It has been suggested that the identity of Brohomaglus may be the same as Brochfael, a grandson of Cunedda, who was associated with Rhufoniog, the cantref and potentially a kingdom situated where the inscribed stone was found (Gruffydd 1989-1990, 3).

However, the name is also fairly common so this association is not definitive (Edwards 2013, 348). On the context of the site, the Welsh Corpus highlights that it appears to have been a cemetery with long-cists and the monument, presumably intially a focal point, has been reused, probably as the sole lintel over one of the graves...such reuse may be compared with Bodedern 1 (AN1) and Llannor 2-4 (CN30-2) (Edwards 2013, 346-7).

The potential fragmentary Ogham inscription has only been noted by Macalister and does not appear on the illustrations in the Welsh Corpus (Edwards 2013, 346-8; Macalister 1945, 377). As only one character, R, was suggested, interpretation and translation is difficult (Macalister 1945, 377).
